awd_titl_txt: A Project to Develop Master's Level STEM Secondary Teachers with Educational Leadership Expertise
awd_abstract_narration:
The Noyce Austin College STEM Education Leadership Scholars (ACSELS) Program is a Track 1 (Scholarships & Stipends) project that will recruit, prepare, and support a minimum of 11 undergraduate majors in the disciplines of biology, biochemistry, chemistry, computer science, mathematics, and physics to become well-prepared secondary school science and mathematics teachers. The ACSELS Program will provide scholarships, internships, and stipends to STEM majors studying to become teachers. Students will receive explicit training in leadership competencies that prepare them for working in high-need school settings as effective STEM teachers, teacher leaders, change agents, and role models for students. Noyce Scholars will complete a five-year program earning a bachelor's degree in a STEM field (biology, biochemistry, chemistry, computer science, mathematics, or physics), a minor in education, and a master's degree in education.

ACSELS Project activities will impact Noyce Scholars at multiple points of their academic and professional careers. These activities include early experiences in the secondary school classroom; leadership behavior development training; mentoring from STEM faculty, education faculty, and in-service teacher mentors; and continued professional development after graduation. Scholars also will be eligible to complete a summer teaching internship in informal STEM education. Leadership behavior development training will be conducted through the STEM Teaching and Research (STAR) Leadership Program and the Leadership Education through Application and Pedagogy (LEAP) Program. The impact of formal leadership behavior development training on preparing STEM majors for teaching careers in high-needs local school districts will be investigated and contribute to knowledge generation.

por.por_cntn:
The Noyce Austin College STEM Education Leadership Scholars (ACSELS) was awarded by the National Science Foundation in 2017 and is in its final no-cost extension year in 2022-2023. The program’s main focus was to provide scholarships, internships, and stipends to recruit, prepare, and retain STEM teacher leaders in high needs schools. The program featured scholarships to provide financial support for students in a unique 5-year Master of Arts in Teaching program at a small liberal arts college in Texas. The cross-campus approach featured a partnership between the STEM faculty and education faculty to integrate leadership development activities into both content and pedagogy courses.

The program had four main components:

1. Scholarships of approximately to support undergraduate tuition in the senior year and graduate year for students seeking certification in secondary STEM fields

2. Paid tutoring opportunities to attract strong undergraduate STEM students to work with local middle and high school students and see if they might have a passion for teaching while supporting STEM education in Title I/rural schools that are close partners with the college’s teacher education program

3. Special STEM education focused Jan term for STEM majors exploring teaching through an experiential teaching focused course in local schools

4. Paid summer internships for future teachers in informal STEM education settings (e.g., STEM museums or summer camps)

5. Mentoring and Professional development to support first-year teachers once in the field

Between 2017-2023, a total of eight Noyce scholars were selected. At the time of this report, six of the seven scholars have pursued certification and completed both their undergraduate degree and their Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) degree. These six scholars have taught some length of time in a high-need local education agency. The final scholar is currently in her first year of teaching in a high-needs local education agency and is scheduled to complete her MAT in May of 2024.
Although the scholarship portion of the program ran smoothly through the award period, the recruitment and retention initiatives ran into roadblocks due to the impact of COVID-19 starting in the spring of 2020. The main impact was on the ability to run internships in the summer of 2020 and the need to decrease the professional development burden and expectations on mentors after the spring of 2020.

The table below outlines the number of participants per year in the recruitment activities.

Table: Number of Participants in Recruitment Activities (2017-2023)

 

Grant

Year 1

2017-2018

Year 2

2018-2019

Year 3

2019-2020

Year 4

2020-2021

Year 5

2021-2022

Year 6

2022-2023

Total
Tutors 6 5 3 4 3  3  24
Interns 0 2 2 0 3  5 12
Jan-Term Students  0 15 15 16 13 15 74


Based on survey, interview data, and participant artifacts, the Jan-term and internship experiences helped develop leadership skills, STEM content and pedagogical knowledge, and provided some insight on how we might develop leadership behaviors and skills in preservice teachers through strategic partnerships. The interview data with the interns provided helpful learnings on how to better design such experiences going forward that maximize learning for interns and efficiency/productivity for the non-profit partners through the use of clear expectations and sharing of the intern’s strengths and expected outcomes.

The data from scholars and their administrators suggest that the leadership development activities integrated into the coursework was beneficial and that the scholars demonstrated exemplary teaching skills once in their own classrooms. Next steps include building a stronger network of scholars after graduation to share professional development/growth opportunities and to continue the focus on developing/integrating leadership development into their own teaching in STEM classrooms.


Last Modified: 09/29/2023
Modified by: Sandy Philipose
